sentences.sentence: By Sharaf SharafeldinSince its inception in 1997, the Muslim Association of Canada (MAC) has worked tirelessly to provide educational and religious programs to Muslims across the country.

From Vancouver to Quebec City, MAC now operates over 50 mosques and schools, provides volunteer opportunities for thousands of Canadians, and serves over 150,000 Canadian Muslims through local chapters.In a recent National Post column, Terry Glavin raised concern about a MAC convention featuring speeches by prominent Muslim scholars who have allegedly made hateful statements in the past.

In light of this, he criticized the Liberals for providing the association with grants.First of all, MAC has used the government funding it has received over the years to secure its mosques from hate crimes and vandalism, provide students with summer jobs, empower women, and combat Islamophobia through education.Secondly, MAC has never permitted a speaker who espouses hatred to use its platform.
Glavin's column raised concern about three specific speakers and statements they were alleged to have made in places unrelated to MAC.

Two of the allegations were unsubstantiated, and one was based on an Islamophobic source.But more importantly, MAC has robust policies around speeches delivered at its centres and conferences that ensures they reflect the true message and universal values of Islam and the Muslim community such as justice, mercy, peace, respect, security, equity, dignity and equality.MAC's recent convention in Toronto was organized in collaboration with over 30 Canadian and international organizations specializing in Islam, family, youth, mental health, relief and humanity, civic involvement, environmental awareness, disability rights, and other subjects.
Thousands of Muslim Canadians attended the convention at the Enercare Centre to learn from a global community of academics, authors, philosophers, influencers, activists and professionals.

Panelists discussed, among other things, tackling rising Islamophobia in Canada, youth leadership, shaping public policy, Islamic finance, and Islamic perspectives on justice, equity and diversity.The convention is only one example of MAC's leadership in Islamic affairs.
The association strives to provide the following through its programming:.
Upholding a balanced and mainstream message of Islam, one that promotes peace and understanding and rejects violence and extremism in all forms..

Helping Muslims develop a Muslim-Canadian identity in which there is no conflict between being one or the other.. Delivering social programs and services across the country, as required by the Muslim community..

Creating spaces and opportunities for Canadian Muslims to come together and find belonging with each other.The understanding of Islam adopted by MAC is not only an intellectual and spiritual manifestation of faith, but also entails a practical implementation reflected in peoples' day to day lives.

This includes helping the poor, supporting immigrants who are in need, caring for seniors and children, guiding youth and even civic engagement.Our faith also requires us to work toward a better society for everyone.
MAC has worked with partners across the country to address food security and homelessness, to support people with disabilities, and to provide relief and aid regardless of faith.

We collaborate with such key organizations as United Way, the Ontario Nonprofit Network, the National Alliance for Children and Youth, and the Students Commission of Canada to drive important conversations about social and policy changes in order to improve our country.For years MAC has worked with interfaith and community leaders to build bridges and promote tolerance and understanding.

The association has always valued Canada's pluralistic society, which embraces diversity and protects human dignity and freedom.As a charity that advances religion, MAC believes that Canadian Muslims must be true to their faith, respectful of others, and enrich society with their faith and service.As a society, we have a choice: we can continue to exclude groups through labels and attacks, or we can choose tolerance and open discussion instead.

I believe that the majority of Canadians support the latter.Special to the National PostSharaf Sharafeldin is President-Strategy of the Muslim Association of Canada and a leader in the Canadian Muslim community.
@COPYRIGHT=© 2022 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
